hero_dishes.name: Pintxos (Basque Tapas)
hero_dishes.description: The Basque word 'pintxo' means 'spike,' referring to the toothpick that holds these perfectly balanced morsels together on slices of bread. Unlike regular tapas, many pintxos are made to order and represent miniature works of culinary art.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Lonely Planet named doing a pintxos bar crawl in San SebastiÃ¡n as the world's #1 food experience. The pintxos scene evolved from simple bar snacks into sophisticated mini-dishes that helped kick off modern Basque cuisine.

The Parte Vieja (Old Town) has over 200 pintxos barsâ€”locals practice 'txikiteo' or pintxos hopping.

hero_dishes.name: Txangurro a la Donostiarra
hero_dishes.description: Spider crab from the Bay of Biscay, stuffed, seasoned, and baked in its own shell. The pintxos version is served as an impressive tartlet that captures the essence of Basque seafood mastery.
hero_dishes.origin_story: This dish represents San SebastiÃ¡n's ('Donostia' in Basque) deep connection to the sea and the Basque tradition of elevating humble seafood into refined cuisine.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Ganbara is the legendary spotâ€”locals and visitors alike line up outside with wine or cider because seating is limited. It's one of San SebastiÃ¡n's most famous dishes.

hero_dishes.name: Grilled Fish and Seafood
hero_dishes.description: Fresh fish, cod fritters, and seafood prepared with classical French techniques blended with unique Basque flavors and local ingredients from the Cantabrian Sea.
hero_dishes.origin_story: San SebastiÃ¡n's cuisine reflects a long-standing reverence for ingredient-driven cooking, seasonality, and a fearless spirit of experimentation that has made the region a culinary paradise.

signature_drinks.name: Txakoli (Basque White Wine)
signature_drinks.description: A slightly sparkling, dry white wine native to the Basque Country, traditionally poured from a height to aerate it and enhance the bubbles.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Locals drink txakoli throughout the day during pintxos crawls, standing at the bar counter and moving from one establishment to another in the narrow stone streets of Parte Vieja.

signature_drinks.name: Basque Cider (Sagardoa)
signature_drinks.description: Natural, slightly sour apple cider served straight from large barrels in traditional cider houses (sagardotegiak).
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: During cider season (January-April), locals gather at cider houses for 'txotx'â€”when the barrel is opened, everyone rushes to catch the stream of cider in their glass, then returns to tables laden with grilled steak and salt cod.

food_culture_notes: San SebastiÃ¡n has an honor system in pintxos barsâ€”you grab food yourself and keep track of what you've eaten by the toothpicks on your plate, then tell the bartender when settling your bill.
The city's culinary scene blends classical French techniques (from its proximity to France) with Basque ingredients and fearless innovation.
Pintxos culture is intensely socialâ€”both locals and tourists roam from bar to bar day and night, sampling different wines and gourmet creations.

The Basque Country has one of the highest concentrations of Michelin stars per capita globally, reflecting centuries of culinary excellence and gastronomic societies (txokos) where locals cook together.
Many pintxos bars have standing room onlyâ€”eating at the counter is part of the authentic experience.
